label: HH1

text: Exelon® is currently approved for marketing in this country, as both capsule and
label: BODY

text: oral solution formulations, for the treatment of mild to moderate dementia of the
label: BODY

text: Alzheimer’s type.
label: BODY

text: The sponsor has provided evidence from two completed clinical studies in
label: BODY

text: support of the efficacy and safety of Exelon® for the proposed new indication.
label: BODY

text: These are:
label: BODY

text: Study 2311, which was randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, and
label: BODY

text: parallel-arm in design
label: BODY

text: Study 2311E1, the open-label uncontrolled extension to Study 2311
label: BODY

text: In addition, the sponsor has performed a non-interventional study (Study 2314) of
label: BODY

text: the validity of a number of assessment scales in the Parkinson’s Disease
label: BODY

text: Dementia (and vascular dementia); partial results for this study have been
label: BODY

text: submitted in this application.
label: BODY

text: The data for these studies as they pertain to the efficacy and safety of Exelon® in
label: BODY

text: this population are summarized below, as are the results of the non-
label: BODY

text: interventional validation study listed above.
label: BODY

text: Efficacy
label: BODY

text: The results of a single randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study (also
label: BODY

text: referred to as the EXPRESS Study) of the efficacy of rivastigmine in the
label: BODY

text: proposed entity of dementia associated with Parkinson’s Disease (also referred
label: BODY

text: to interchangeably as Parkinson’s Disease Dementia) have been submitted in
label: BODY

text: this application.  The main features of this study were as follows
label: BODY

text: This was a randomized (2:1 [Exelon®:Placebo]), double-blind, placebo-
label: BODY

text: controlled, parallel-arm study
label: BODY

text: The key inclusion criteria for the study were as follows

text: Safety
label: BODY

text: Study 2311
label: BODY

text: This study has already been summarized above. Salient safety findings for this
label: BODY

text: study were as follows.
label: BODY

text: The incidence of nausea, vomiting, and tremor was appreciably higher in the
label: BODY

text: rivastigmine group than in the placebo group; a similar adverse event profile was
label: BODY

text: seen in the key controlled clinical trials of Exelon® in Alzheimer’s Disease
label: BODY

text: Several treatment-emergent adverse events that may have represented a
label: BODY

text: worsening in the motor manifestations of Parkinson’s Disease, and tremor in
label: BODY

text: particular, were more frequent in those treated with Exelon® than in those
label: BODY

text: treated with placebo. However, changes in UPDRS total and individual motor
label: BODY

text: scores, probably a more objective measure of change in the motor
label: BODY

text: manifestations of Parkinson’s Disease than the incidence of treatment-emergent
label: BODY

text: adverse events, showed no meaningful difference between treatment groups.
label: BODY

text: Study 2311E1
label: BODY

text: This was a 24-week open-label uncontrolled extension to Study 2311 intended
label: BODY

text: primarily to evaluate the safety and tolerability of Exelon® in the study
label: BODY

text: population. Patients given the option of enrolling in this study had either
label: BODY

text: completed the double-blind treatment phase of Study 2311 or discontinued early
label: BODY

text: during that study, but returned for all the remaining scheduled efficacy
label: BODY

text: assessments without significant protocol violations. Regardless of their previous
label: BODY

text: treatment assignment, patients enrolled in the extension study were all re-titrated
label: BODY

text: to a flexible dose of Exelon® that ranged from 1.5 mg BID to 6.0 mg BID, based
label: BODY

text: on tolerability.
label: BODY

text: 433 patients enrolled in Study 2311 were eligible to enroll in Study 2311E1, of
label: BODY

text: whom 334 patients actually consented to participate in, and 273 patients,
label: BODY

text: completed the latter study.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Non-Interventional Validation Study (Study 2314)
label: BODY

text: This 4-week cross-sectional study was intended to evaluate the validity and
label: BODY

text: reliability of several measures of cognition, activities of daily living, executive
label: BODY

text: function and behavior in patients with Parkinson’s Disease Dementia and
label: BODY

text: vascular dementia, and to compare the performance of the same measures in
label: BODY

text: those conditions with their performance in Alzheimer’s Disease. This submission
label: BODY

text: contains an interim report that only pertains to Parkinson’s Disease Dementia.
label: BODY

text: The interim report indicates that 55 patients with Parkinson’s Disease Dementia
label: BODY

text: (diagnosed using the DSM-IV criteria) and 58 patients with Alzheimer’s Disease
label: BODY

text: (diagnosed using the NINCDS-ADRDA criteria) were enrolled in the study;
label: BODY

text: patients with each diagnosis were further grouped into mild and moderate
label: BODY

text: categories based on Mini-Mental Status Examination scores of 18 to 24 and 10
label: BODY

text: to 17, respectively, at study entry. The efficacy instruments evaluated were the
label: BODY

text: ADAS-Cog, Global Deterioration Scale, ADCS-ADL, D-KEFS Verbal Fluency
label: BODY

text: Test, Ten-Point Clock Test, Trailmaking Tests A and B, Neuropsychiatry
label: BODY

text: Inventory, including Neuropsychiatry Inventory-Distress, and Cognitive Drug
label: BODY

text: Research Computerized Assessment System tests for the assessment of
label: BODY

text: attention. Each enrolled patient was to be evaluated using these measures at
label: BODY

text: baseline and Week 4; all but 2 patients, both in the Parkinson’s Disease
label: BODY

text: Dementia group, completed  their evaluations.
label: BODY

text: The results of this study have been interpreted as demonstrating the following:
label: BODY

text: That the ADAS-Cog score can differentiate between dementia associated with
label: BODY

text: Parkinson’s Disease of mild and moderate severities, as can the scores for
label: BODY

text: several of the other instruments evaluated in this study
label: BODY

text: That the ADAS-Cog and several other efficacy measures had test-retest
label: BODY

text: reliability in dementia associated with Parkinson’s Disease
label: BODY

text: That the ADAS-Cog scores correlated with those of several other efficacy
label: BODY

text: instruments in dementia associated with Parkinson’s Disease, whether the latter
label: BODY

text: measures assessed cognition or other domains
label: BODY

text: A factor analysis that compared populations with Parkinson’s Disease Dementia
label: BODY

text: and Alzheimer’s Disease on ADAS-Cog sub-item scores had indicated that the
label: BODY

text: sub-items grouped differently in each  population, suggesting that the cognitive
label: BODY

text: and behavioral profiles in these populations might differ

text: 1. Background
label: HH1

text: This submission, a Supplemental New Drug Application, seeks the approval of
label: BODY

text: Exelon® (rivastigmine tartrate) for the treatment of “mild to moderate dementia
label: BODY

text: associated with Parkinson’s Disease.”
label: BODY

text: The data supporting this application are stated to be derived entirely from the
label: BODY

text: results of the EXPRESS (“Rivastigmine for Dementia Associated with
label: BODY

text: Parkinson’s Disease”) Study, also referred to as Study 2311. An open-label
label: BODY

text: uncontrolled extension to that Study 2311, designated as Study 2311E1 has also
label: BODY

text: bee completed.
label: BODY

text: A meeting to discuss this submission and the results of the EXPRESS Study was
label: BODY

text: held between the Division and sponsor on May 18, 2005, and is summarized
label: BODY

text: later in this review.
label: BODY

text: Exelon® (rivastigmine tartrate) is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor drug approved
label: BODY

text: by this Agency on April 21, 2000, for the treatment of mild to moderate dementia
label: BODY

text: of the Alzheimer’s type, as immediate-release capsule and oral solution
label: BODY

text: formulations. Please refer to the primary reviews of NDAs #s 20823 (for the
label: BODY

text: immediate-release capsule formulation) and 21025 (for the oral solution
label: BODY

text: formulation) for full details.
label: BODY

text: In this review, the terms “Exelon®” and “rivastigmine” are used interchangeably.
label: BODY

text: Also note that “dementia associated with Parkinson’s Disease” is also referred to,
label: BODY

text: apparently interchangeably, as Parkinson’s Disease Dementia (PDD) in the
label: BODY

text: sponsor’s submission.
label: BODY

text: The Biometrics Reviewer of this submission is Dr Juan (Joanne) Zhang.
label: BODY

text: 4.2 DSM-IV Criteria For Dementia Due To Parkinson’s Disease
label: HH1

text: 294.1    Dementia Due To Parkinson’s Disease
label: BODY

text: The essential feature of Dementia Due To Parkinson’s Disease is the presence of dementia that is judged to be of
label: BODY

text: direct pathophysiological consequence of Parkinson’s disease. Parkinson’s disease is a slowly progressive
label: BODY

text: neurological condition, characterized by tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. Dementia has been
label: BODY

text: reported to occur in approximately 20%-60% of individuals with Parkinson’s disease and is more likely to be present in
label: BODY

text: older individuals or in those with more severe or advanced disease. The dementia associated with Parkinson’s disease
label: BODY

text: is characterized by cognitive and motor slowing, executive dysfunction and impairment in memory retrieval. Declining
label: BODY

text: cognitive performance in individuals with Parkinson’s disease is frequently exacerbated by depression. Findings on
label: BODY

text: physical examination include the characteristic abnormal motor signs of resting tremor, evidence of slowness and
label: BODY

text: poverty of movement (such as micrographia), or muscular rigidity and loss of associated movements. At autopsy,
label: BODY

text: neuronal loss and Lewy bodies are evident in the substantia nigra. There are a number of syndromes that manifest
label: BODY

text: with dementia, Parkinsonian movement disorders, and additional neurological features (e.g., progressive supranuclear
label: BODY

text: palsy, olivopontocerebellar degeneration, and Vascular Dementia). Some individuals with Parkinson’s disease and
label: BODY

text: dementia are found at autopsy to have coexisting neuropathology indicative of Alzheimer’s disease or of diffuse Lewy
label: BODY

text: body disease.
label: BODY

text: 5. Efficacy Outcome Measures And Selected Additional
label: HH1

text: Instruments Used In Efficacy Study
label: HH1

text: These instruments are outlined below:
label: BODY

text: 5.1 Alzheimer’s Disease Assessment Scale – Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-
label: HH1

text: Cog)
label: HH1

text: This is a validated instrument  consisting of the following 11 items: Word Recall
label: BODY

text: Task, Naming Fingers and Objects, Orientation Questions, Constructional Praxis
label: BODY

text: Task, Following Commands, Ideational Praxis Task, Word Recognition Task,
label: BODY

text: Rating of Spoken Language, Rating of Language Comprehension, Rating of
label: BODY

text: Word Finding Difficulty and Rating of Ability to Recall Test Instructions. The total
label: BODY

text: scores range from 0-70 with higher scores indicating greater cognitive
label: BODY

text: impairment.
label: BODY

text: 5.2 Alzheimer’s Disease Cooperative Study – Clinician’s Global Impression
label: HH1

text: Of Change (ADCS-CGIC)
label: HH1

text: This instrument provides for a rating of overall (global) change from baseline by
label: BODY

text: an independent clinician experienced in the assessment of patients with
label: BODY

text: dementia. The term “independent” implies that the rater is not to be involved in
label: BODY

text: any additional manner in the evaluation and/or treatment of patients enrolled in
label: BODY

text: this study
label: BODY

text: Assessments will be performed at baseline and at subsequent visits. It is
label: BODY

text: recommended that the baseline interview be conducted by 2 independent raters,
label: BODY

text: one designated as the primary rater and the other as a backup. Post-baseline
label: BODY

text: ratings are to be conducted solely by the primary rater or, in his/her absence, by
label: BODY

text: the back-up rater.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: and evaluations. At all subsequent visits, the rater is to rely (for baseline data)
label: BODY

text: solely upon information obtained during the baseline assessment of the patient
label: BODY

text: and caregiver by that rater (including written notes and, if available, the baseline
label: BODY

text: interview audiotape or videotape). At post-baseline visits, data obtained directly

text: 5.7 Neuropsychiatry Inventory
label: HH1

text: This is a validated instrument that assesses the following 12 domains
label: BODY

text: (subscales): delusions, hallucinations, agitation/aggression,
label: BODY

text: depression/dysphoria, anxiety, elation/euphoria, apathy/indifference, disinhibition,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: interviewing a caregiver; if a symptom subsumed by a particular domain is
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: frequency and severity, with a maximum score of 12. The maximum total score
label: BODY

text: for the 12 domains (the sum of the subscale scores) is 144 with a higher score
label: BODY

text: indicating greater behavioral abnormality.

label: BODY

text: 7.1.2.1 Primary
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: a treatment period of 24 weeks in patients with Parkinson’s Disease Dementia.

label: BODY

text: 7.1.3 Design, Duration, Sample Size, Dosage
label: BODY

text: This was to be a 24-week randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-
label: BODY

text: arm study.
label: BODY

text: About 540 patients were to be randomized 2:1 to Exelon® or placebo (i.e., about
label: BODY

text: 360 patients to Exelon® and about 180 patients to placebo).
label: BODY

text: The overall study design is summarized in the following table:
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: levels for Exelon® are shown in the following table
label: BODY

text: Dose Level
label: BODY

text: Exelon® Dose
label: BODY

text: 1.5 mg BID
label: BODY

text: 3.0 mg BID
label: BODY

text: 4.5 mg BID
label: BODY

text: 6.0 mg BID
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: • For the titration period
label: BODY

text: All patients were to begin at Dose Level 1
label: BODY

text: After 4 weeks, the dose was to be increased to Dose Level 2 unless
label: BODY

text: tolerability was impaired
label: BODY

text: Subsequent increases to Dose Levels 3 and 4 were to be based on the
label: BODY

text: tolerability of the preceding dose, and were to be considered only after 4
label: BODY

text: weeks of treatment at the previous dose
label: BODY

text: In the event of poor tolerability, an investigator could decide to reduce a
label: BODY

text: dose to the preceding level, with increases to the next dose level being
label: BODY

text: made as clinically indicated
label: BODY

text: All patients were expected to have found their highest tolerated dose by
label: BODY

text: Week 16.

text: 7.3 Sponsor’s Conclusions
label: HH1

text: In this trial, which was conducted in dementia associated with Parkinson’s
label: BODY

text: Disease, the efficacy of Exelon® in a dose of 3 to 12 mg/day for 24 weeks was
label: BODY

text: significantly superior to that of placebo on a measure of cognition (which was
label: BODY

text: assessed by the ADAS-Cog) and on a measure of the clinical global rating of
label: BODY

text: change (ADCS-CGIC). The primary objective of the study was therefore
label: BODY

text: achieved
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 7.4 Study Abstract
label: HH1

text: Emre M, Aarsland D, Albanese A, Byrne EJ, Deuschl G, De Deyn PP, Durif F, Kulisevsky J, van
label: BODY

text: Laar T, Lees A, Poewe W, Robillard A, Rosa MM, Wolters E, Quarg P, Tekin S, Lane R.
label: BODY

text: Rivastigmine for dementia associated with Parkinson's disease. N Engl J Med. 2004;351:2509-18
label: BODY

text: BACKGROUND: Cholinergic deficits are prominent in patients who have dementia associated with
label: BODY

text: Parkinson's disease. We investigated the effects of the dual cholinesterase inhibitor rivastigmine in such
label: BODY

text: patients.
label: BODY

text: METHODS: Patients in whom mild-to-moderate dementia developed at least 2 years after they received a
label: BODY

text: clinical diagnosis of Parkinson's disease were randomly assigned to receive placebo or 3 to 12 mg of
label: BODY

text: rivastigmine per day for 24 weeks. Primary efficacy variables were the scores for the cognitive subscale of
label: BODY

text: the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale (ADAS-cog) and Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study-
label: BODY

text: Clinician's Global Impression of Change (ADCS-CGIC). Secondary clinical outcomes were the scores for
label: BODY

text: the Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study-Activities of Daily Living, the 10-item Neuropsychiatric
label: BODY

text: Inventory, the Mini-Mental State Examination, Cognitive Drug Research power of attention tests, the Verbal
label: BODY

text: Fluency test, and the Ten Point Clock-Drawing test.
label: BODY

text: RESULTS: A total of 541 patients were enrolled, and 410 completed the study. The outcomes were better
label: BODY

text: among patients treated with rivastigmine than among those who received placebo; however, the differences
label: BODY

text: between these two groups were moderate and similar to those reported in trials of rivastigmine for
label: BODY

text: Alzheimer's disease. Rivastigmine-treated patients had a mean improvement of 2.1 points in the score for
label: BODY

text: the 70-point ADAS-cog, from a baseline score of 23.8, as compared with a 0.7-point worsening in the
label: BODY

text: placebo group, from a baseline score of 24.3 (P<0.001). Clinically meaningful improvements in the scores
label: BODY

text: for the ADCS-CGIC were observed in 19.8 percent of patients in the rivastigmine group and 14.5 percent of
label: BODY

text: those in the placebo group, and clinically meaningful worsening was observed in 13.0 percent and 23.1
label: BODY

text: percent, respectively (mean score at 24 weeks, 3.8 and 4.3, respectively; P=0.007). Significantly better
label: BODY

text: outcomes were seen with rivastigmine with respect to all secondary efficacy variables. The most frequent
label: BODY

text: adverse events were nausea (affecting 29.0 percent of patients in the rivastigmine group and 11.2 percent
label: BODY

text: of those in the placebo group, P<0.001), vomiting (16.6 and 1.7 percent, P<0.001), and tremor (10.2 and 3.9
label: BODY

text: percent, P=0.01).
label: BODY

text: CONCLUSIONS: In this placebo-controlled study, rivastigmine was associated with moderate improvements
label: BODY

text: in dementia associated with Parkinson's disease but also with higher rates of nausea, vomiting, and tremor.
label: BODY

text: Ranjit B. Mani, MD, HFD-120 Medical Review

text: 7.5 Additional Observations And Comments By Agency Statistical
label: HH1

text: Reviewer About Study 2311
label: HH1

text: The Agency Biometrics Reviewer for this submission, Dr Joanne Zhang, has
label: BODY

text: made the following main observations, and drawn the overall conclusions
label: BODY

text: outlined below regarding the efficacy results of this study
label: BODY

text: 7.5.1  Observations
label: BODY

text: • Dr Zhang has independently performed the protocol-specified primary
label: BODY

text: efficacy analyses and has obtained results that agree with those obtained
label: BODY

text: by the sponsor. However she has the following concerns about these
label: BODY

text: analyses
label: BODY

text: An assumption underlying the use of an analysis of covariance (used in
label: BODY

text: this instance for the primary efficacy analysis of the ADAS-Cog) is that
label: BODY

text: the data be normally distributed. Dr Zhang tested the residuals for the
label: BODY

text: analysis of covariance model used for the ADAS-Cog analysis with the
label: BODY

text: Wilk-Shapiro test; the hypothesis of normality of the residuals was
label: BODY

text: rejected (p-values of 0.0072 for Week 16, and < 0.0072 for Week 24). Dr
label: BODY

text: Zhang therefore used a non-parametric method, the Wilcoxon rank sum
label: BODY

text: test, for the analysis of the ADAS-Cog and demonstrated statistically
label: BODY

text: significant differences favoring Exelon® over placebo at both Weeks 16
label: BODY

text: and 24 (p < 0.005 at both timepoints)
label: BODY

text: Another assumption underlying the use of an analysis of covariance
label: BODY

text: model to test for differences between the drug and placebo groups is that
label: BODY

text: of a constant regression relationship between the 2 treatment groups; if
label: BODY

text: that assumption is violated it is indicative of an interaction between the
label: BODY

text: treatment groups and independent variable (i.e., the baseline value) and
label: BODY

text: this interaction renders difficult the interpretation of the final treatment
label: BODY

text: effect due to the drug. Dr Zhang tested the heterogeneity of the slopes for
label: BODY

text: the 2 treatment groups for the ADAS-Cog at Weeks 16 and 24 in the
label: BODY

text: intent-to-treat plus retrieved dropouts population; while the slopes at
label: BODY

text: Week 16 were similar, those at Week 24 were statistically significantly
label: BODY

text: different, as indicated by the table below. Therefore, if the analysis of
label: BODY

text: covariance model is relied on to predict the treatment effect due to the
label: BODY

text: drug, the drug will be underestimated at low baseline values and
label: BODY

text: overestimated at high baseline values. The results of the sponsor’s
label: BODY

text: analysis of covariance applied to the ADAS-Cog change from baseline
label: BODY

text: data at Week 24 therefore need to be interpreted with caution
label: BODY

text: 7.6.2 Safety Of Exelon®
label: BODY

text: The safety data for this study indicate that the adverse event profile of Exelon® in
label: BODY

text: the study population was largely similar to that seen in clinical trials with
label: BODY

text: Alzheimer’s Disease, in that there was a distinctly higher frequency of nausea,
label: BODY

text: vomiting, diarrhea, and anorexia in those exposed to Exelon® than in those
label: BODY

text: exposed to placebo.
label: BODY

text: Of special relevance to a population with Parkinson’s Disease, was the
label: BODY

text: observation that tremor (which was not further characterized) was recorded as a
label: BODY

text: treatment-emergent adverse event in about 10% of those received Exelon® and
label: BODY

text: 4% of those who received placebo in this study (in the controlled clinical trials of
label: BODY

text: Exelon® that were conducted prior to its approval for Alzheimer’s Disease,
label: BODY

text: tremor was seen in about 4% of  those who received Exelon® and 1% of those
label: BODY

text: who received placebo). Several other adverse events that may conceivably have
label: BODY

text: been linked to a worsening in Parkinson’s Disease were also more frequent in
label: BODY

text: those treated with Exelon® than in those treated with placebo, but their incidence
label: BODY

text: in the Exelon®-treated group was lower than that of tremor. However, changes in
label: BODY

text: UPDRS total motor scores, probably a more objective measure of change in the
label: BODY

text: motor manifestations of Parkinson’s Disease than the incidence of treatment-
label: BODY

text: emergent adverse events, showed no meaningful difference between treatment
label: BODY

text: groups.

text: 10. Summary Of Earlier Meeting Between Division And Sponsor

text: Regarding This Application.
label: HH1

text: A meeting was held with the sponsor on May 18, 2005, at which the results of
label: BODY

text: Study 2311 (EXPRESS Study) were discussed in outline and on a preliminary
label: BODY

text: basis, in the context of a sponsor proposal to expand the current indication for
label: BODY

text: Exelon® to include “the treatment of mild to moderate dementia associated with
label: BODY

text: Parkinson’s Disease.”
label: BODY

text: The following is a summary of the salient views conveyed by the sponsor’s team
label: BODY

text: at that meeting.
label: BODY

text: The entity of dementia associated with Parkinson’s Disease (as exemplified by
label: BODY

text: the patients enrolled in the EXPRESS Study) is linked to distinctive
label: BODY

text: neuropathological findings (i.e., widespread Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites),
label: BODY

text: with more recent publications strongly suggesting that the contribution of  co-
label: BODY

text: existing Alzheimer’s-type neuropathological changes (e.g., senile plaques and
label: BODY

text: neurofibrillary tangles) to the dementia are minor
label: BODY

text: A cholinergic deficiency state is the basis for dementia associated with
label: BODY

text: Parkinson’s Disease, just as with Alzheimer’s Disease
label: BODY

text: The population enrolled in the EXPRESS trial was distinct from that enrolled in
label: BODY

text: the pre-approval clinical trials of rivastigmine in Alzheimer’s Disease (and was
label: BODY

text: actually excluded from those trials)
label: BODY

text: Although patients enrolled in the EXPRESS trial were not selected based on
label: BODY

text: those neuropsychological deficits that, according to the DSM IV definition of
label: BODY

text: “Dementia Due To Parkinson’s Disease,” (294.1) are distinctive for that disorder
label: BODY

text: (i.e., “cognitive and motor slowing, executive dysfunction, and impairment in
label: BODY

text: memory retrieval”), selecting patients based on the extent of such deficits is
label: BODY

text: unlikely to help differentiate them from patients with Alzheimer’s Disease
label: BODY

text: The results of the EXPRESS Study are sufficiently robust for that study alone to
label: BODY

text: be the basis for the expansion of the current claim to include dementia
label: BODY

text: associated with Parkinson’s Disease, especially since the mechanism by which
label: BODY

text: rivastigmine may have its effect in that condition and in Alzheimer’s Disease may
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 294.1    Dementia Due To Parkinson’s Disease
label: BODY

text: The essential feature of Dementia Due To Parkinson’s Disease is the presence of dementia that is judged to
label: BODY

text: be of direct pathophysiological consequence of Parkinson’s disease. Parkinson’s disease is a slowly
label: BODY

text: progressive neurological condition, characterized by tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability.
label: BODY

text: Dementia has been reported to occur in approximately 20%-60% of individuals with Parkinson’s disease and
label: BODY

text: is more likely to be present in older individuals or in those with more severe or advanced disease. The
label: BODY

text: dementia associated with Parkinson’s disease is characterized by cognitive and motor slowing, executive
label: BODY

text: dysfunction and impairment in memory retrieval. Declining cognitive performance in individuals with
label: BODY

text: Parkinson’s disease is frequently exacerbated by depression. Findings on physical examination include the
label: BODY

text: characteristic abnormal motor signs of resting tremor, evidence of slowness and poverty of movement (such
label: BODY

text: as micrographia), or muscular rigidity and loss of associated movements. At autopsy, neuronal loss and
label: BODY

text: Lewy bodies are evident in the substantia nigra. There are a number of syndromes that manifest with

text: 15.2.3.2 What are the implications of the diagnostic criteria for dementia with
label: BODY

text: Lewy bodies for the entity of Parkinson’s Disease Dementia?
label: BODY

text: Another entity that combines dementia with features of Parkinson’s Disease is
label: BODY

text: dementia with Lewy bodies for which revised diagnostic criteria have recently
label: BODY

text: been proposed (see McKeith et al [2005] below). In the more recent medical
label: BODY

text: literature, this entity has generally been distinguished from Parkinson’s Disease
label: BODY

text: Dementia by the (arbitrary) “one-year rule” criterion where the onset of dementia
label: BODY

text: within 12 months of the onset of parkinsonism is stated to be consistent with
label: BODY

text: dementia with Lewy bodies whereas if parkinsonism has been present for more
label: BODY

text: than 12 months prior to the onset of dementia, the condition is considered to
label: BODY

text: represent Parkinson’s Disease Dementia. The neuropathological abnormalities
label: BODY

text: that underlie both conditions are considered to be similar with changes
label: BODY

text: considered distinctive for Parkinson’s Disease being combined with other
label: BODY

text: pathology, notably Alzheimer-type changes. Whether these entities are the same
label: BODY

text: disease or separate distinct entities is still a matter of some controversy, although
label: BODY

text: the consensus view appears to be that they are the same neurobiological entity
label: BODY

text: with clinical phenotypes that differ, based solely on the arbitrary “one-year rule.”
label: BODY

text: Note that the revised criteria for the diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies
label: BODY

text: include the following “central” (required) feature: “Dementia defined as
label: BODY

text: progressive cognitive decline of sufficient magnitude to interfere  with normal
label: BODY

text: social or occupational function. Prominent or persistent memory impairment may
label: BODY

text: not necessarily occur in the early stages, but is usually evident with progression.
label: BODY

text: Deficits on tests of attention, executive function, and visuospatial ability may be
label: BODY

text: especially prominent.” The publication that describes these revised diagnostic
label: BODY

text: criteria (McKeith et al [2005]) further states the following: “The cognitive profile of
label: BODY

text: dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) comprises both cortical and subcortical
label: BODY

text: impairments with substantial attentional deficits and prominent executive and
label: BODY

text: visuospatial dysfunction.  A “double discrimination” can help differentiate DLB
label: BODY

text: from Alzheimer disease (AD), with relative preservation of confrontation naming
label: BODY

text: and short and medium term recall as well as recognition, and greater impairment
label: BODY

text: on verbal fluency, visual perception and performance tasks.” These cognitive
label: BODY

text: abnormalities are similar to those described by a number of authors as being
label: BODY

text: distinctive for Parkinson’s Disease Dementia
label: BODY

text: Thus the same (reportedly) distinctive clinical features may be common to both
label: BODY

text: dementia with Lewy bodies and Parkinson’s Disease Dementia, while both
label: BODY

text: entities may also have the same neuropathological basis.
